Title:
Comparative phylogeography in a specific and obligate
pollination antagonism
Abstract:
In specific and obligate interactions the nature and
abundance of a given species can have important effects on the survival
and population dynamics of associated organisms. In a phylogeographic
framework, we therefore expect that the fate of organisms interacting
specifically is also tightly interrelated. Here we investigate such a
scenario by analyzing the genetic structures of species interacting in
an obligate plant-insect pollination lure-and-trap antagonism involving
Arum maculatum (Araceae) and its specific Psychodid (Diptera) visitors
Psychoda phalaenoides and Psycha grisescens as a case-study. Because the
plant depends on the insect but the opposite is not true, we expect the
genetic structure of the plant to be related with the historical
pollinator availability, yielding incongruent phylogeographic patterns
between the interacting organisms. Based on insect mtDNA sequences and
plant AFLP genome fingerprinting, we inferred the large-scale
phylogeographies of each species and the distribution of genetic
diversities through the sampled range, and evaluated the congruence in
their respective genetic structures using hierarchical analyses of
molecular variances (AMOVA). Because the composition of pollinator
species varies at the scale of Europe, we also examined its association
with the spatial genetic structure of the plant. Our findings indicate
that while the plant presents a spatially well-defined genetic
structure, this is not true for the insects. Patterns of genetic
diversities also show different distributions among the three
interacting species. Phylogeographic histories of the plant and its
pollinating insects are thus not congruent, a result that would indicate
that plant and insect lineages do not share the same glacial and
postglacial histories. However, the genetic structure of the plant can,
at least partially, be explained by the type of pollinators available at
a regional scale. Differences in life-history traits of available
pollinators might therefore have influenced the genetic structure of the
dependent organism, the plant, in this antagonistic interaction.
